titleStmt.title: How to edit the TEI Guidelines
titleStmt.author: Lou Burnard

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished first draft for review by TEI Technical council

revisionDesc.change: merged back in Seb's notes on Jenkins

body.p: This document is intended to set out the way things are currently managed in the editing of the source files from which the TEI Guidelines and schemas are generated. General notes on the rationale for this state -- why it is the way it is -- may be added here later. The intention is to provide information for Council members wishing to contribute actively to the continued development and maintenance of those source files, which we refer to collectively in this document as the Guidelines.

div.head: Logical organisation of the Guidelines
div.p: The only chapters not organised in this way are those which do not introduce or define particular modules.

div.head: Physical organization: the ODD files
div.p: Each element, class, and macro defined in the Guidelines is declared within its own XML file, containing an elementSpec, classSpec, or macroSpec as appropriate. These files are in the directory Source/Specs. For example, the file Source/Specs/abbr.xml contains the element spec for the abbr element.

Each chapter of the Guidelines is stored in a file called Source/Guidelines/xx/YY-name.xml where xx is the language (currently only en or fr), YY is the two letter identifier for each chapter (see ) and name is the name of the module being defined by that chapter.

The file Source/guidelines-xx.xml (where xx is either en or fr) is the driver file for the whole shebang. It contains system entity declarations for each of the documents making up the P5 source. These entities are then referenced throughout the source to embed the required component at the right place.At one point we considered using xInclude to do this instead, but decided against it for reasons which now escape me.

Hence, to add a new element (say saintName) you might proceed as follows:
Write a new file saintName.xml containing an elementSpec for your new element and add it to the Specs folder.
Add a declaration like this to the existing driver file <!ENTITY saintName SYSTEM "Specs/saintName.xml">
Edit the source of the relevant chapter (presumably ND-namesdates.xml) to include a reference to the element spec (like this &saintName;), and also some discussion of its usage. The former can appear anywhere, but good practice is to include it in an alphabetic list of such declarations near the end of the relevant section. You can also use a specList to reference the description from your new spec within the body of the text, like this:
This module also defines the following canonical element:

div.head: General
div.p: The Guidelines are a reference manual, not a tutorial. You should not talk down to the reader, but assume they have a reasonably well-informed knowledge of the subjects under discussion. Make copious use of cross references, rather than repetition.

Bear in mind however that your reader may not have English as their first language. Avoid needlessly complex sentences and unnecessarily obscure terminology. Make sure that technical terms are glossed on their first appearance: this should be in the chapter on XML in the case of XML-related terminology. If you want to provide other references, do so as footnotes, using the note element.
Provide bibliographic citations for any other standards (etc) referenced, following the existing style. Do not introduce bibliographic citations simply in order to demonstrate your learning.

A separate document (copied below) attempts to summarise current house style with reference to well known vexed issues about spelling, punctuation, etc. The goal of these rules is to avoid inconsistency, and also (wherever possible) to avoid producing text which is markedly either British or American English.

div.head: Examples
div.p: The purpose of an example is to illustrate a specific element or feature. Do not include irrelevant encoding which does not contribute to this primary goal. If such encoding is unavoidable (eg to make your example valid), then it must be explained in the supporting text.

Wherever possible, choose your examples from real documents and provide bibliographic citations for them in the file BIB-Bibliography.xml. Use the corresp attribute on the egXML element to link an example to its source note. Note that the xml:lang attribute is mandatory on exemplum: this is to ensure that the ODD processor knows which examples to choose in a given context.
All examples should be valid against a modified TEI schema in which any element can act as a root element: this validity is checked during the build process.

As well as a validity check, the build process looks at cross-references. Since the Guidelines is a single XML document, IDs must be unique across the text and the examples. Consequently, any xml:id attribute values appearing in your examples must be unique within the text of the whole of the Guidelines. Furthermore, any target (etc.) values which do not point to anything in the source will be flagged with a warning during the build process.

div.head: Making a change to the Guidelines
div.p: The Guidelines are maintained in a Sourceforge subversion repository. "Subversion" is a widely-used source control system, and we don't explain further here how to use. To make changes in the repository you need to have an account on Sourceforge and "developer" rights on the TEI project. We don't explain here how to obtain a sourceforge account: go to the website http://www.sf.net to find more information about this. To get developer rights, if you don't already have them, you need to contact one of the project administrators whose email addresses are listed on the TEI project page at http://tei.sf.net.

list.item: Use a Subversion client to update your local copy of the source text before you make any changes in it.
Make your changes. Make sure your source is still valid against the p5odds.rnc schema.
If you have a locally installed P5 build environment, make sure you can still build, and that the examples are still valid.

If you don't have a locally-installed P5 build environment, just use subversion to check your updated version back in and wait for the Continuous Integration (CI) server Jenkins to assess your work; see further .

div.p: Error messages may appear at any stage. Please do not leave the source in an invalid state (it makes life unnecessarily difficult for others). If you cannot immediately fix a validity error, revert your change while you think about it.

Error messages appearing during the make test phase usually indicate that your changes are in conflict with the Birnbaum Doctrine, which decrees that changes in the Guideline schemas should not invalidate existing documents. You may wish to discuss the specific issue with other Council members.
When making changes to the ODDs, it is advisable to add testfiles to the Test directory to ensure that your changes have been carried out correctly.

div.head: Jenkins setup
div.p:
Jenkins divides the work of building P5 into three linked stages: Test, Documentation and the final assembly. The work they do is as follows:
Test stage: this monitors https://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/tei/trunk/P5, the part of the TEI sourceforge subversion repository where the P5 source is stored. If any change is detected, it runs make clean validate test exemplars
Documentation stage: this also updates itself from the Subversion repository before it runs, but is triggered by the success of the Test run, not directly by monitoring Subversion. It runs make clean dist-doc validate-html
Final stage: this is triggered by a successful run of the Documentation stage, gets copies of artefacts produced during the first two stages, and then does rm -f dist-source.stamp dist-schema.stamp dist-test.stamp dist-database.stamp dist-exemplars.stamp, followed by make dist deb and make teiwebsiteguidelines. It makes available release/xml/**, release/doc/**,*.zip,tei-p5-*_*,teiwebsiteguidelines.zip on the web.
See for details on how to configure Jenkins. The files currently used for this purpose are accessible in the Sourceforge Documents/Editing/Jenkins directory.

The Jenkins plugins which should be installed are as follows:
Copy Artifact Plugin
Adds a build step to copy artifacts from another project.
Jenkins CVS Plug-in
Integrates Jenkins with CVS version control system.
Emotional Hudson plugin
This funny plugin changes the expression of Mr. Hudson in the background when your builds fail.
Green Balls
Because green is better than blue!
Hudson Job Configuration History Plugin
Job history plugin for hudson.
Log Parser Plugin
Maven Integration plugin
Plot plugin
This plugin provides generic plotting (or graphing) capability.
Hudson SCP publisher plugin
This plugin uploads build artifacts to repository sites using SCP (SSH) protocol.
Jenkins Subversion Plug-in
Hudson WebSVN2 plugin
This plugin integrates WebSVN browser interface for Subversion to Hudson. Entries in change logs will by hyperlinked to the specified files/diffs in WebSVN.

div.head: Building the release
div.p:
The TEI maintains a number of distinct packages on Sourceforge. The source for all of them is maintained in a Subversion repository. The main published packages are :
P5
The main TEI P5 source Roma
The web application Stylesheets
The stylesheet library tei-emacs
TEI customisation of emacs
Two other packages, I18N, which provides input for the internationalization utilities used in producing P5, and TEIOO which provides P5 support for Open Office, are also maintained, but unpublished.

The rest of this section describes how to make a new release for the main P5 package, but similar procedures apply to the others. The instructions assume you are working on a Linux or MacOSX system with a command line, and know (more or less) how to use the standard GNU make utility.

div.head: Creating a new file release
div.p: First edit the file VERSION, and make it say what you are about to release. Now check that the source is clean and tested. When you are happy that these are what you want, do make dist. This makes a single zip file with all the TEI P5 deliverables in, called tei-versionumber.zip.
If you also say make deb, and you have the Debian devscripts packages installed, six Debian packages will be created (see further below).

If you do not have a build system yourself, the Jenkins CI server (currently experimentally at ) will watch Subversion, make all the tests, and rebuild everything after any change. It will create the zip archive and Debian packages for you.

div.head: Uploading file releases to Sourceforge
div.p:
The zip file tei-versionumber.zip is what we put up on Sourceforge. If you did not create this in your own build process, you can take a copy from . You now need to upload this file to the Sourceforge download area by using one of the supported methods, such as secure FTP or rsync. For example
rsync -e ssh tei-1.9.0.zip rahtz,tei@frs.sourceforge.net:/home/frs/project/t/te/tei/TEIP5-All
Further details of the upload procedure are provided in the Sourceforge Wiki.

div.head: Making Debian packages
div.p: A Debian package combines a set of source files with Debian-specific metadata and support files. For each of the packages mentioned above, there is a directory under P5 named debian-packagename/debian containing the necessary additional material. The command make deb goes into each of the directories and builds the package, creating 6 corresponding .deb, .build and .changes files. As above, if you cannot build these yourself, grab from

Now you can move the Debian files to a repository somewhere (tei.oucs.ox.ac.uk:/home/tei/teideb, if you have access) and rebuild the package database. Building Debian packages is extensively documented on the web, but there is a lot more to it than described here (such as the content of the control files for post-installation, pre-removal, init scripts, menus etc).

The important TEI-related Debian packages are
tei-emacsTEI Emacs setup
tei-oxygenoXygen XML editor
tei-p4-docTEI Guidelines (P4)
tei-p4-liteTEI P4 Lite
tei-p4-schemaTEI P4 Schemas/DTDs
tei-p4-xslTEI P4 XSLT stylesheets
tei-p5-docTEI Guidelines
tei-p5-exemplarsTEI exemplar customiza
tei-p5-schemaTEI Schemas/DTDs
tei-p5-sourceTEI sources/DTDs
tei-p5-testTEI test files
tei-p5-xslTEI XSLT (1.0) stylesheets
tei-p5-xsl2TEI XSLT (2.0) stylesheets
tei-xsl-commonTEI XSLT stylesheets, shared files
Some of these packages have dependencies on other packages, which will get pulled in as needed (trang, jing etc).

div.head: Installing files on the TEI web site
div.p:
Most users of the TEI will want to download and install either the debian packages or the full release files from sourceforge. For convenience however we also provide copies of the current dtds, schemas and stylesheets on the main TEI web site. These copies are provided for the following reasons:
to service the rendering web pages themselves
to let Roma find resources
to provide a service of fixed URLs for DTDs and schemas
The files are organised as indicated below (). There is a script in P5/Utilities/tei-install.sh which can be run to pull the latest artefacts from Jenkins, and put them in the right place on the TEI web site. The script requires at least two parameters, one to specify the Jenkins package name, and the other the version number required :
./tei-install.sh --package=TEIP5 --version=1.9.0

div.head: Setting up Roma and eXist
div.p: Roma needs access to XSLT stylesheets, P5 Relax NG schemas, and an eXist database of TEI P5. Where it finds these is determined by the file roma/config.php (on the main TEI web site, this is in the /usr/share/tei-roma/ directory). However, this varies between sites, so what is distributed is config-dist.php.

How does TEI P5 get into eXist? Using the script tei-database-rebuild, which is installed into /usr/bin. Running that on the TEI web site will attempt to install the files into both the standard locations and the archive of releases.

div.head: Setting up OxGarage
div.p: The Roma installation at depends on the web service supplied by OxGarage (currently at ) to provide ODD manipulation. The OxGarage configuration is set to look for its stylesheets and copy of TEI P5 in the standard location (under /usr/share/xml/tei), using symbolic links, so no special case is needed to have it take notice of a new release.

div.head: Chapter codes
div.p: Following a lengthy debate in the Council as to whether the two-character codes originally used to identify individual chapters should be dropped in favour of longer more human-readable names, a compromise solution was reached in which the two character codes were retained as prefixes to longer human-readable names. The same two-character codes are also used to identify the HTML and PDF files generated during the release process.

In most chapters, the two character code is also used as a prefix for the xml:id values given to each div element. Note that every div element carries an xml:id value, whether or not it is actually referenced explicitly elewhere in the Guidelines.

Note that files with names beginning REF contain only divGen elements: their content, which provides the reference documentation (sections A1 to A5 inclusive), is automatically generated during the build process.

div.p:

div.head: Naming conventions
div.p: TEI naming conventions have evolved over time, but remain fairly consistent.

list.label: generic identifiers
list.item: An element and attribute identifiers should be a single natural language word in lowercase if possible. If more than one word is conjoined to form a name, then the first letter of the second and any subsequent word should be uppercased. Hyphens, underscores, dots etc are not used within element or attribute names.
list.label: class names
list.item: Class names are made up three parts: a name, constructed like an element name, with a prefix and optionally a suffix. The prefix is one of model. or att. and indicates whether this is a model or an attribute class. The suffix, if present, is used to indicate subclassing: for example att.linking.foo is the foo subclass of the attribute class att.linking
list.label: xml:id values
list.item:
The conventions for these vary somewhat. Most of the older chapters of the guidelines have consistently constructed identifiers, derived from the individual section headings. Identifiers must be provided for:-
every div, whether or not it is explicitly linked to elsewhere
every bibliographic reference in the BIB.xml file
